Sometimes, people need to really focus on their work for a long time. Many bosses say you can concentrate as much as you want, as long as you still reply to their emails quickly. This is probably why a lot of people who work in offices like to follow this kind of routine.

In the 1980s, a journalist named Walter Isaacson was doing really well at Time magazine. He was becoming well-known, and other writers were noticing him. For example, Christopher Hitchens called him one of the best magazine journalists in America. It was the perfect time for Isaacson to write an important book, which is a big deal for journalists. He decided to write about six important people from the early Cold War and teamed up with another young editor, Evan Thomas, to create a big book called The Wise Men: Six Friends and the World They Made.

This book came out in 1986 and got great reviews. The New York Times said it was a detailed story, and the San Francisco Chronicle praised the authors for their work. A few years later, Isaacson became the editor of Time magazine and later became the CEO of a think tank. He also wrote popular biographies about famous people like Benjamin Franklin and Steve Jobs.

What I find interesting about Isaacson is not just what he achieved, but how he wrote his first book. I have a personal connection to this story. My uncle, John Paul Newport, was also a journalist in New York and rented a beach house with Isaacson. My uncle remembers how impressive Isaacson’s work habits were. He would go to the bedroom to write while everyone else relaxed outside. He would work for twenty minutes to an hour, and then come back down looking just as relaxed as everyone else. It seemed like the work didn’t stress him out; he just enjoyed writing whenever he had the chance.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Walter Isaacson, a successful journalist, focused on his work habits while writing his first book. He balanced writing with relaxation, showing how effective work routines can lead to success. His story highlights the importance of dedication and time management in achieving goals.
